I always thought bats were at a big disadvantage to birds. Bird wings can be far more aerodynamic, and can have chord thickness. Bats will not likely evolve this. Bats are incredibly vulnerable and fragile, many birds are not. An injury to a bat's wing likely means permanent incapacitation; birds just lose a few feathers and quickly grow them back. Feathers are way lighter and can provide buoyancy and superior warmth.  The range of bird flight (fast, slow, huge, tiny, efficient like the albatross), is far greater than that of bats, and birds are far more common on the planet, and occupy every climate.  Bats are much more rare.  The one thing I think is clever is this business of hanging upside down.  This saves energy, but is a problem as far as pooping and peeing.        Birds win. My ears are bleeding. You're supposed to be a PhD candidate, Destin. Two errors in only 3 consecutive words. Hint: you got "and" correct.

First, you lead with everyone else, ending with yourself. "You, Jimmy, my daughter, my dog, and I ..."

Second, which sounds right: "me am gonna ..." or "I am gonna ..."??? Always remove the others and then construct your sentence with what sounds right when you construct the sentence about only yourself. It will tell you right away which to use, I or me? Same test applies when including others: "him and me are gonna..." or "he and I are gonna"? Remove yourself, then is it "him is gonna ..." or is it "he is gonna ..."?

For these reasons, the grammatically-correct sentence is "you and I are gonna ..."

Maybe some remedial English (it was called Bonehead English during my day) would be in order when you head back to college to get your PhD. If you're gonna be the Intertube's perfessor, you oughta learn to speak good United States.

If you watch the bats wings as it flaps, you can see the "fingers" in the wing moving independently. I thought about this for some time and wondered why this was. This independent motion of the flapping of its wings created a very interesting affect: it causes the top most portions of the wings to fill up with air. This seems silly right?

Watch the wings closely and in its flight motion, it appears as if it is scooping air into the upper portion of its wings with its fingers, creating a sort of billowing parachute effect on the wing. It is generating its own lift! By simply flapping its muscled appendages, it is generating enough lift to suspend itself in the air, similarly to how a swimmer suspends themselves in a stationary spot in a pool.

I don't know, but here's a guess: Birds have been around for longer and have thus evolved to be more diverse. As bats came along later, they had to fill in an ecological niche (most bats fly at night and eat night-insects, so they don't compete with most birds, who mainly fly during the day). I would argue that bats are more successful in their ecological niche, and don't evolve to replace birds because birds are already well suited for other ecological niches, and could out-compete bats there.

So, maybe bats which fly in confined spaces may have tail membranes, whereas bats which spend more of their time in open areas (and therefore do not need as much maneuverability, but need less drag) do not have them?

If a bat has a moveable tail membrane, it can enhance the maneuverability. If the bat changes the alpha of the tail, a ccw vortex is shed which induces a cw vortex around the tail (Kelvin and Kutta?). This causes the velocity over the top to increase meaning pressure decreases more, (Bernoulli) which increases lift. So by moving around a tail membrane, bats can instantly change the lift at their trailing edge and so doing create a moment which can help them maneuver.

My stab at tail membrane question:
It intuitively seems related to stability. While flaying perfectly straight and level, the wings behave symmetrically and balance each other out, but this would not happen while pitching to a side. The tail membrane might allow them to counter that lack of symmetry to keep their body more stable (I don't know exactly where the "vortexes" play into this, however)
Lacking a membrane might allow for sharper movements like flipping upside-down etc.

Bees: 11,000
Typical house-fly: 2,000
Hummingbirds: up to 200 (depends on species)
Airplane: 0
